Etymology. This species is named for the collector of the holotype , D. S. Chandler.

Diagnosis.
Stenosagola chandleri
is similar in appearance to other members of the
connata
group but can be distinguished by the shape of the male genitalia ( Fig. 12b ) and the frontal rostral lobe of the female head bearing a pair of blunt processes (
Fig. 12g
).
Description. Length 1.3–1.5 mm ( Fig. 7f–g ). Head : Wingless male head approximately
Distribution. Mid Canterbury ( MC ), Nelson ( NN ), Marlborough Sounds ( SD ), and southern part of South Island, New Zealand ( Fig. 13 , squares).
Habitat. Most specimens were collected by sifting forest litter. One specimen was taken in a pitfall trap, and several specimens were collected from grass tussocks.
